summary: new type gosling viral enteritis (NGVE) is an infectious disease that affects goslings less than 30 days of age. it is caused by an adenovirus called the NGVE virus (NGVEV) NGVE has resulted in significant economic losses due to the high mortality of the offspring of breeder geese. previous studies showed that apoptosis can be induced by NGVEV in duck embryo fibroblasts and the host cells of duck embryos. apoptotic morphological changes were observed by light microscopy and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) the experimental group (n = 100) and observation group (n = 30) were DNA ladder analysis from the proventriculus, gizzard, small intestine, cecum, rectum, harderian gland, thymus, BF, and spleen of the infected goslings is shown in Fig. 4. no obvious DNA ladder patterns were observed in samples from the control birds during the entire experiment. apoptosis and necrosis were detected in the early and late NGVEV-infection phase. the presence and quantity of apoptotic cells increased with infection time until 9 days PI. apoptosis was readily observed in the lymphoid and digestive organs. virus-induced lymphocytic apoptosis is involved in pathogenesis of many viral infections. cellular and humoral immune functions are markedly depressed in central as well as peripheral immune organs after NGVEV infection. apoptosis and necrosis were widely detected in the digestive organs. be useful for achieving a better understanding of the mechanisms involved in NGVEV infection.
